rev.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/75.185.29.18|75.185.29.18]] ([[User talk:75.185.29.18|talk]]) to last version by Peterlewis
rev.diff:
Line 16: Line 16:
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
